1.  Introduction:

The City of Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant, located in Milton, Florida, stores and uses two regulated toxic chemicals in processes as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) chemical accident prevention standard, commonly referred to as the USEPA Risk Management Program (RMP).  According to the RMP standard, facilities that use or store a covered substance at or above the threshold quantity are required to comply with the requirements of the rule. 

Chlorine is utilized at the Milton WWTP for the disinfection of treated wastewater.  Typically, two full and one partial one-ton cylinders are stored for this purpose.  The City also stores up to six full and empty 150 pound cylinders for use as disinfectant in their potable water system.  The maximum possible stockpile of chlorine, based on the conservative assumption that all vessels are full, would be 6,900lbs.  The EPA RMP threshold quantity for chlorine is 2,500lbs, which is exceeded by the maximum storage capacity of the Milton WWTP.

Sulfur dioxide is used to dechlorinate treated wastewater prior to discharge to surface waters.  Typically, two full and one partial one-ton cylinders are stored for this purpose.  The maximum possible stockpile of sulfur dioxide, based on the conservative assumption that all vessels are full, would be 6,000lbs.  The EPA RMP threshold quantity for sulfur dioxide is 2,500lbs, which is exceeded by the maximum storage capacity of the Milton WWTP.

2.  Overview of accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the Milton WWTP: 

Accidental releases are prevented by applying standard procedures for operations and maintenance of regulated processes, regular inspections of process equipment, leak detection equipment, and system design features where line breaks result in system shut down, and power outages are avoided by implementation of a backup generator system.  

The facility has an Emergency Response Plan with detailed procedu

res to follow in the event of many types of emergency conditions.  The purpose of this Emergency Response Plan is to provide clear, concise directions during an emergency.  Its function is to prevent physical harm to staff, public, environment, or facilities.  The plan is a key to preparedness and was developed using EPA, DEP, County, and City guidelines.  It includes a series of action plans for specific situations and list emergency supplies, emergency organizations, and preparedness training.  

Specific emergency scenarios covered by the plan include Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide Leaks, Civil Disorder, Cold Weather, Fire, Hurricanes, Lightning/Electrical Storms, Threats, Threat Identification Sheet, Tornadoes and Windstorms.

3. Description of the Milton WWTP's overall approach to chemical safety:

The general approach to chemical safety at the Milton WWTP is by the application of standard procedures for operations and maintenance of regulated processes, regular inspections of process equipment, leak detection equipment, and system design features where line breaks result in system shut down, and power outages are avoided by implementation of a backup generator system.  

WWTP staff is committed to the safety of their chemical process, and the plant in general, and all facets of this approach undergo regular review by staff and operators.

4.  Provide a description of your facility, processes, products, and regulated substances: 

The City of Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant was constructed to provide centralized treatment of wastewater that is collected from the Milton wastewater service area.  Treated wastewater is first chlorinated for disinfection, and then dechlorinated (by the addition of sulfur dioxide) to make benign the treated wastewater that is discharged to the Blackwater River, in accordance with rules detailed in the Florida Administrative Code, and enforced by FDEP. 

Chlorine is utilized at the Milton WWTP for the disinfection of treated wastewater

.  The chlorination system is located within the Chlorine Building, an all-metal building constructed on a raised foundation with vented enclosing walls on three sides, which contains two interconnected one-ton liquid chlorine containers, a chlorinator, and various safety equipment.

While the plant is manned sixteen hours each day, the chemical treatment building is normally unmanned.  Wastewater treatment operators visit the building several times daily, and respond to any trouble alarms that may occur.

Typically, two full and one partial one-ton cylinders are stored for chlorination of treated wastewater.  The City also stores up to six full and empty 150 pound cylinders for use as disinfectant in their potable water system.  The maximum possible stockpile of chlorine, based on the conservative assumption that all vessels are full, would be 6,900lbs.  The EPA RMP threshold quantity for chlorine is 2,500lbs, which is exceeded by the maximum storage capacity of the Milton WWTP.

Sulfur dioxide is utilized at the Milton WWTP for the dechlorination of disinfected wastewater prior to discharge to the Blackwater River.  The sulfonation system is located within the Sulfur Dioxide Building, an all-metal building constructed on a raised foundation with vented enclosing walls on three sides, which contains two interconnected one-ton liquid chlorine containers, a chlorinator, and various safety equipment.

Sulfur dioxide is used to dechlorinate treated wastewater prior to discharge to surface waters.  Typically, two full and one partial one-ton cylinders are stored for this purpose.  The maximum possible stockpile of sulfur dioxide, based on the conservative assumption that all vessels are full, would be 6,000lbs.

The EPA RMP threshold quantity for sulfur dioxide is 2,500lbs, which is exceeded by the maximum storage capacity of the Milton WWTP.

5.  Describe the general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:

The City of Milton Waste

water Treatment Plant, located in Milton, Florida, stores and uses two regulated toxic chemicals in processes as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) chemical accident prevention standard, commonly referred to as the USEPA Risk Management Program (RMP).  The provisions of the standard are set forth in Chapter 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations in Part 68 (40 CFR 68).  According to the RMP standard, facilities that use or store a covered substance at or above the threshold quantity are required to comply with the requirements of the rule. 

In addition to the RMP standard, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) is intended to prevent the release of hazardous chemicals that could result in on-site consequences involving employees.  The Florida Division of Safety adopted the PSM standard as 38I-20 of the Florida Administrative Code (FAC), which includes the public sector such as municipally owned water and wastewater treatment facilities.
Since the Facility stores chlorine and sulfur dioxide in quantities that exceed the threshold quantities for both the RMP and PSM standards, the Facility is subject to the requirements of the RMP and PSM standards for both chemical stockpiles.

Florida is a "Federal OSHA State" as the OSHA PSM has been adopted into Florida rules.  Since Florida does not have a delegated OSHA program, regulated processes involving regulated toxic substances, such as the use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, are subject to the Program 3 conditions of the RMP.

In order to fulfill the Program 3 requirements of the RMP, a Prevention Program must be prepared in accordance with 40 CFR 68, Subpart D, and therefore must include:

Practices that have been developed by the plant designers and staff to ensure the safety of the regulated processes include standard procedures for operations and preventive maintenance of regulated processes, regular inspections of process equipment, utilization of state-of-the-art process equipment, leak detection equipment, and system design features where line breaks result in system shut down, and power outages are avoided by implementation of a backup generator system.  Training of plant staff is ongoing and recurring, and is an extension of the training that is required to become licensed wastewater operators.  The Milton WWTP uses accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators, and performs hazard reviews of equipment and procedures, and has implemented an auditing and inspection program.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine or sulfur dioxide supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, and the presence of chlorine and sulfur dioxide detectors.

6.  Describe the five-year accident history:

In the last 5 years, one minor accident occurred with a regulated process in September 2006.  This event did not result in any offsite consequences due to the small quantity (<1lb) of sulfur dioxide released.  Two staff members received medical treatment for inhalation, but did not require hospitalization.  

The challenge of this event was met by plant staff with revisions to standard procedures for handling the regulated chemical, and training for staff was revised to clearly detail how to avoid a similar accident in the future.

7. Describe the emergency response program:

The facility has an emergency response program, which has been coordinated with the City of Milton Fire Department, which is a

member of the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This program includes an emergency response decision tree and a notification plan.

The facility has an Emergency Response Plan with detailed procedures to follow in the event of many types of emergency conditions.  The purpose of this Emergency Response Plan is to provide clear, concise directions during an emergency.  Its function is to prevent physical harm to staff, public, environment, or facilities.  The plan is a key to preparedness and was developed using EPA, DEP, County, and City guidelines.  It includes a series of action plans for specific situations and list emergency supplies, emergency organizations, and preparedness training.  

Specific emergency scenarios covered by the plan include Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide Leaks, Civil Disorder, Cold Weather, Fire, Hurricanes, Lightning/Electrical Storms, Threats, Threat Identification Sheet, Tornadoes and Windstorms.

All responses to non-weather emergency scenarios begin with notification of the appropriate fire or police resources through 911.  These scenarios detail information to convey to first responders to protect the welfare of both plant staff and provide notification to nearby communities.  Additionally, ongoing training of plant staff is provided by local fire departments.  This facilitates cooperation between plant staff and first responders as well as providing emergency response training to plant staff.

Leak detection equipment and online alarms also provide protection from releases of the regulated processes.

8.  Planned changes to improve safety 

No changes to the regulated processes are planned at this time.
